Award.AwardTitle: Optimal and Structured Frames with Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Han
DMS-1106934

This project has three main goals: (i) Develop the theory and algorithms for optimal dual (and fusion) frames for erasures and for sparse signal reconstruction. (ii) Develop the theory of the frame spectrum for fractal measures that can provide much faster reconstruction (for example, compared to the classical Shannon sampling method) for functions that are concentrated on fractal-like regions. (iii) Investigate the connections between the Feichtinger frame conjecture for group representation frames and related problems such as the Kadison-Singer problem.

In today's digital world efficient data processing has become more demanding in all kinds of applications. The principal investigator studies fundamental questions in harmonic and functional analysis that are applicable in areas such as wireless communications, radar, seismic sensing, image processing, reliable classification of features in biomedical images, and algorithms for the compensation of data loss in digital transmission of signals. The optimal dual frame design problems for erasures and sparsity are directly related to basic issues in redundant representation and transformation of signals. The investigation leads to applicable tools for problems in engineering and information applications, and provides theoretical analysis and algorithmic construction for computationally efficient frames.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Frame theory has a wide range of applications in today's digital world where efficient data processing has become more demanding in all kinds of applications. In this project the principal investigator investigated several fundamental problems in frame theory and functional analysis that are applicable in areas such as wireless communications, image processing, reliable classification of features in biomedical images, quantum information, coding theory and algorithms for the compensation of data loss in digital transmission of signals.

 

With the support of this project the PI and his collaborators were able to achieve all the main objectives outlined in the project.

(i) Characterized the optimal encoding-decoding frames (devices) in applications where erasures occurred during data transmissions. Established the theoretical foundation and new construction algorithms for such optimal frames or fusion frames when probability is involved with erasures.

(ii) Made significant progresses on the problem related the convergence and divergence properties of Fourier series on Cantor-type fractal, and the existence problem of Fourier frames for fractal measures.  

(iii)  Developed the dilation theory for bounded linear maps and arbitrary operator-valued measures, and established the connections with the frame theory. This led to a new theory that unifies the theory of several research aspects surrounding the dilation theory. Highlights include the new discovery of the connection between bounded linear map dilations and the well-known Similarity Problem for bounded homomorphisms on C*-algebras, and new connections with McKay’s theory of primitivity.

(iv) Completed the theoretical investigation for the possibility of recovering signals with unknown erasure locations and disordered data set, and designed new signal recovering algorithms based on the theoretical results.

(v) Supervised three Ph.D students.  Two of them graduated and obtained their first job either as Tenure-Track Assistant Professor or research scientist. Mentored several young research visitors and collaborated on the topics within the scope of this project. 

(vi) Mentored several other graduate students and undergraduate students through weekly seminars and honor's thesis on the topics within the scope of this project.

The new findings, results and algorithms that were developed from this project have impact on advancing the research of frame theory, functional analysis and their applications to many problems within or outside the mathematical discipline. In particular, the findings on the connections between frame theory and dilation theory of bounded linear maps may lead to possibility of establishing a theory for  non-commutative frames over von Neumann algebras,  which has applications in quantum information theory. The theoretical results and the new construction algorithms for optimal frames can be directly applied to engineering and information applications where redundant representation and transformation of signals are needed for the purpose of stable reconstructions.
